fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Engineering degree is offered by the School of Engineering. Students select one of the following engineering disciplines: bioengineering, chemical engineering, civil engineering, electrical engineering, or mechanical engineering. The program requires a minimum of 180 units, with at least 96 units in engineering and related subjects. Students must also complete a set of required courses, including mathematics, physics, and chemistry.
shortProgramDescription: The B.S. in Engineering at Stanford provides a foundational education in engineering principles, preparing students for professional practice or further study.
classHighlights: Mathematics and Science: The program requires a strong foundation in mathematics and science, including Calculus I-III (MATH 19-21), Differential Equations (MATH 51 or CME 100), Probability and Statistics (STAT 116), Mechanics (PHYSICS 41 or 61), Electricity and Magnetism (PHYSICS 43 or 63), and Chemistry (CHEM 31 or 31X).

Engineering Fundamentals: Students must complete a set of foundational engineering courses, such as Introduction to Engineering (ENGR 40M or ENGR 76), and additional courses in their chosen engineering discipline.

Engineering Disciplines: Students choose one of the following engineering disciplines: bioengineering, chemical engineering, civil engineering, electrical engineering, or mechanical engineering, and complete the required courses for that discipline.
Design and Innovation: The program emphasizes design and innovation, with courses that require students to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems.
Technical Electives: Students must complete a set of technical electives, chosen from a range of engineering and related courses, to deepen their knowledge in their chosen discipline.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental engineering principles to solve complex problems.
Design and develop innovative solutions to real-world challenges.
Communicate technical concepts effectively to diverse audiences.
Work effectively in teams to achieve common goals.
Understand the social, environmental, and economic context of engineering practice.
creditRequirements: Minimum 180 quarter units, with at least 96 units in engineering and related subjects
additionalInformation: Students must declare a specific engineering discipline and complete the required courses for that discipline. The program is designed to be completed in 4 years, with a typical course load of 15-18 units per quarter.
